topic.title: Node Availability
topic.shortdesc: When enabled, the auto-failover feature automatically fails over any node identified as unresponsive or unavailable.

body.p: Full Administrators and Cluster Administrators can enable auto-failover feature.

Automatic failover is disabled by default. When you enable auto-failover, it is enabled for all services except the Index Service. The timeout settings determine how long a node can be unresponsive before auto-failover is triggered.

section.title: Using the UI
section.p: The Node Availability panel is as follows:
The following three checkboxes are provided:

ul.li: Enable auto-failover after n seconds for up to nn event: After the timeout period set here as n seconds has elapsed, and up to the limit of actionable events set here as nn, an unresponsive or malfunctioning node is failed over. Any replica copies of data, indexes, or query engines are promoted to active, elsewhere in the cluster. This feature is only available when three or more nodes are present in the cluster. See Using Automatic Failover for more information.

Enable auto-failover for sustained data disk read/write failures after n seconds: After the timeout period set here as n seconds has elapsed, a node is failed over if it has experienced sustained data disk read/write failures. This checkbox can only be checked if Enable auto-failover after n seconds for up to nn event has also been checked.

Enable auto-failover for of server groups: Server-failover is enabled. This checkbox (which can only be checked if Enable auto-failover after n seconds for up to nn event has also been checked) should only be checked if three or more homogenous server groups have been established, and capacity is available to absorb the load of a failed-over group.

section.p: The following, additional option is available for Ephemeral Buckets:

Checking the checkbox ensure that if a node that contains active Ephemeral Buckets is unavailable, its replicas are promoted to active status, as appropriate, to avoid data-loss. Note that this may leave the cluster in an unbalanced state, and therefore require a rebalance.

section.title: Using the CLI
section.p: The automatic failover settings can be changed using the setting-autofailover command in couchbase-cli.

section.title: Using the REST API
section.p: The automatic failover settings can be changed using the REST API /settings/autoFailover endpoint.
